fr:mainmatter.html:p: A reflexive pair is the categorical translation of a reflexive relation. It is defined as a pair of arrows \partial _0, \partial _1 : X \rightrightarrows Y with a common section r : Y \to X, i.e. an arrow r such that \partial _0 \mathbin {\circ } r = \partial _1 \mathbin {\circ } r = \textrm {id}_Y. A coequalizer of a reflexive pair is called a reflexive coequalizer.

Let G : \mathcal {D} \to \mathcal {C} be a functor with a left adjoint F. M = G \mathbin {\circ } F is the corresponding monad on \mathcal {C}. This gives a comparison functor K : \mathcal {A} \to \mathcal {C}^M.

html:ol.html:li: If \mathcal {D} has all coequalizers (we can weaken this to reflexive coequalizers), then K has a left adjoint.
If moreover G preserves these reflexive coequalizers, the unit \textrm {Id} \to K \mathbin {\circ } L is an isomorphism.
Finally, if G reflects isomorphisms, then the counit L \mathbin {\circ } K \to \textrm {Id} is also an isomorphism, making G monadic.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the final point, we would like the coequalizer of FG\epsilon , \epsilon : FGFGX \rightrightarrows FGX to be isomorphic to X. If we apply G to the diagram, we get an isomorphism to GX by the previous point. So if G reflects isomorphisms, we’re done.
